metadata.case_name: Surendra Pal Arora & Ors. v. Saraswati Arora & Ors.

facts.text: Bhim Sain Arora lost his first wife on April 14, 1959.

Bhim Sain had four daughters and one son (Surendra Pal Arora, first appellant) by first wife; two daughters married affluent, Shanta (22, unmarried at time), Rita (13, minor studying Loreto Convent Simla); son not living with father; strained relations with son, Shanta, Rita.
On August 16, 1960, Bhim Sain complained to police against son Surendra Pal for insulting, abusing, threatening violence, stealing jewellery and cash.
On August 25, 1960, Bhim Sain filed formal complaint against son under s.350 IPC for theft, abuse, threats, removing gun.
Bhim Sain advertised for wife in Sunday Tribune Ambala September 1960: widower merchant seeks Punjabi Hindu unmarried/issueless widow >30.
Saraswati (35, doctor) replied October 4, 1960 via 'Mrs. Puri' (her mother).
Correspondence: Amalendu Chaudhuri (PA to Bhim Sain) replied October 11, 1960; Puri replied December 26, 1960; both seeking companionship, no procreation interest.
Saraswati arrived Calcutta January 30, 1961 with mother, stayed with sister Col. Harish Chandra Vigh.
Bhim Sain visited Col. Vigh January 31, February 1, 2, 1961.
Tea party February 3, 1961 at Bhim Sain's; agreed marriage February 7, 1961; Special Marriages Act notice ante-dated due to time shortage.
February 8, 1961: Bhim Sain informed Col. Vigh of will execution; went to Vigh's with Saraswati; met Nelson Das; signed draft will attested by Vigh and Das.
Bhim Sain lived with Saraswati nearly 3 years; died January 18, 1964.
Post-death, son wrote to Saraswati mentioning will ignorance, seeking partition.
Solicitors correspondence; Saraswati applied probate September 14, 1964; caveat by son.
Rita did not contest initially; late appeal dismissed.
October 1960 agreement: Bhim Sain provided for Shanta maintenance/marriage with son, Rita maintenance/residence (no marriage mention).
Children ignored Bhim Sain at Shanta's marriage, did not visit before death, no grandson visit.
Calcutta High Court Appeal No. 78 of 1967 judgment September 30, 1970 granted probate.

legal_issues.text: Whether the will dated February 8, 1961 of Bhim Sain Arora was duly executed, attested, genuine, and executed with knowledge of contents and free will, or obtained by fraud, coercion, undue influence, importunity by Saraswati and Col. Vigh.
Whether Bhim Sain was prevented by force/threats from executing a further equitable will.

Presence of suspicious circumstances: Saraswati's participation, unnatural dispositions excluding mother/children, interested witnesses, no lawyer, sudden execution, unsatisfactory evidence, date alteration, separate attestation typing.

petitioner_arguments.text: Will not genuine; signature not real; testator unaware of contents, no instructions to solicitors, not read/explained.
Execution obtained by fraud, coercion, undue influence, importunity by wife and Col. Vigh as condition of marriage.
Prevented by force/threats from executing further equitable will for mother, minor Rita.

Suspicious circumstances including unnatural exclusion of family, Saraswati's benefit/participation, no disinterested witnesses, no lawyer, sudden will next day marriage, evidence interested, date alteration, separate attestation.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Halsbury's Laws of England Vol. 17 Art. 1311 (presumption undue influence in engagement)

respondent_arguments.text: Will duly executed/attested in presence of Col. Vigh and Nelson Das; testator sound mind, knew contents.
No undue influence; marriage companionship-based; testator hostile to children due prior complaints/theft; provided for children earlier; expected to outlive mother, marry Rita.
Saraswati present but not involved in execution; independent professional woman, not gold-digger.

court_reasoning.text: Propounder discharges onus by proving signature, sound mind, understanding nature/effect, free will, attestation in presence; suspicious circumstances must be explained.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Elements established; lower courts rejected contests.

court_reasoning.text: Strained family relations explain exclusions: complaints against son pre-advertisement; daughters lived with brother; prior agreement for maintenance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Natural for testator to protect new wife from hostile family.

court_reasoning.text: No presumption undue influence from engagement/marriage in India; social conditions differ; must prove undue influence under Evidence Act s.103,111,114.
Date alteration by testator himself probable; witnesses confirm Feb 8; no motive to ante-date.
No evidence revocation attempt or prevention; children behaved shabbily post-marriage.

holdings.text: Will genuine, duly executed/attested; testator sound disposing mind, aware nature/effect, free will; no fraud/undue influence/coercion; suspicious circumstances explained.
No presumption undue influence from marriage engagement in Indian conditions; proof required.

precedents_cited.case_name: H. Venkatachala Iyengar v. B. N. Thimmajamma Ors
precedents_cited.relevance: Propounder onus; suspicious circumstances to explain.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rani Purnima Devi and Anr v. Kumar Khagendra Narayan Deb Another
precedents_cited.relevance: Onus on caveator for undue influence; propounder explain suspicions.

precedents_cited.case_name: Motibai Hormusjee Kanga v. Jamsetjee Hormusjee Kanga
precedents_cited.relevance: Onus on propounder for capacity; on caveator for undue influence; foolish acts upheld if comprehended.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jagmohan Singh v. State of P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Caution against transplanting foreign experience without context.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smt. Kamla Kunwar v. Ratan Lal
precedents_cited.relevance: Wills exceptional in India; scrutinize circumstances rigorously.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Burden on party alleging undue influence; presumptions of fact.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Complaint against son for criminal intimidation.

statutes_cited.name: Special Marriages Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice given but ante-dated for marriage.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld Calcutta High Court and trial court grant of probate to Saraswati Arora of Bhim Sain Arora's will dated February 8, 1961; all issues against appellants; will valid.
outcome.relief_granted: Probate confirmed in favour of Saraswati.

key_quotes.text: After all, ultimately it is the conscience of the Court that has to be satisfied, as such the nature and quality of proof must be commensurate with the need to satisfy that conscience and remove any suspicion which a reasonable man may, in the relevant circumstances of the case, entertain.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Standard for proving will amid suspicions.

key_quotes.text: A man may act foolishly and even heartlessly if he acts with full comprehension of what he is doing the Court will not interfere with the exercise of his volition.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Upholds testator's free will despite unnatural dispositions.

key_quotes.text: There is no presumption of law or fact in this country that a woman to whom a man is engaged to be married is in a position to dominate his will so as to over-ride his own real intentions.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects foreign presumption of undue influence in marriage.
